title: In Chiafalo v. Washington, will the Supreme Court rule that the state of Washington's fining of presidential electors for failing to vote for the nominee of their party is unconstitutional?
preds: 7/6/20: "Electoral College voters can be forced to abide by state popular vote, Supreme Court says" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/06/supreme-court-electoral-college-ruling-states-can-force-electors-to-abide-by-popular-vote.html)
The Supreme Court will determine that electors must represent the wished of their state and that this requirement is implied in the U.S. Constitution and directly stated in the state law.

No ruling likelihood + likelihood that SC rules as constitutional if they do rule on it. Politics for both parties and fairness that a fine is the price of violating oath make it highly likely ruling would be 'no' anyway.

The court is considering extending their time in order to address some issues leads me to believe this will not be cast to the side.  The wording of the question, about fining being unconstitutional will be resolved, and I give it about a 30% chance that fines are unconstitutional based on the arguments in the previous two decisions. The state cannot fine people it elects to represent them for not voting the way they choose.  At the same point, the question of electors voting on whether they can be mandated by the state is a different issue. When it comes to Congress, we think of our leaders as elected to make decisions based on their best judgment. That appears to be the same intent when it comes to the Electoral College ... not a great plan, but a plan nonetheless. Send people of our party we trust to vote on things the way we ask them to.  So the issue of deciding they have to vote a particular way has parallels in looking at the Senate and House, and would beg the question as to whether the state could bind them to vote Democrat or Republican on issues.

States are generally given constitutional primacy on how elections are conducted

Not following the majority vote is akin to voter suppression.  In this current climate, allowing electoral college voters to cast a different vote than the majority will need to be heavily discouraged and a fine is a good way to insure compliance to the majority

The original-intent strict-construction crowd are presumably suffering the tortures of the darned on this one.  It is obvious from everything their 18th-Century heroes wrote about this that they meant electors to exercise their own judgement.  It has been obvious from about the John Adams administration forward that the original model has been consigned to the dustbin of history.  It is not obvious, but a possibility terrifying to those very people, that truly independent electors could destroy the two-party system that has secured their comfy jobs and ideological certainty.   Comfort and certainty will win, albeit disguised as deep and abiding reverence for democracy--as long as democracy doesn't interfere with gerrymandering or unlimited cash showers.  Listen for the screams of the logic as it is torn apart to explain this ruling, which I expect to be nearly unanimous.
Lowering a tad. They will not find it unconstitutional but will write some rules. It will say the way it was done was illegal.

I think there are several factors confounding the crowd here:
1) as with any political question there are going to be those who can't separate their wishes from their predictions.
2) The way the question is written is confusing (because it's complicated, not because GJO did a bad job of writing the question).  I think the odds are heavily towards "no" and the fact that the crowd is higher reflects the issues above more than actual probabilities.

Oral argument was not of much help in predicting the case result. It is true though that Brett Kavanaugh's questioning focused on the "chaos" argument. "Chaos" argument, btw, favours the Electors because most of US electoral history has not been marked by chaos even though states by and large have not fired or disciplined the few faithless Electors that turn up from time to time. Gorsuch at one point during the oral argument in Baca raised a ludicrous concern. "Suppose Mr. Baca had asked Congress to count his vote." I could not believe what I was hearing. How on Earth could he have "asked Congress to have his vote counted"? Read the XII Amendment. Electors don't go about sending their individual ballots to Washington DC. A single sealed list of votes is sent from each state, signed and certified by that state's Electors. In the case of Colorado, it was a list signed by Baca's replacement and all the other Electors. Why ask such a nonsense question.

Wow.   First the lawyer in Chiafalu was a disaster. 
Secondly, the Kavanaugh was neither an originalist nor a textualist.    That was a complete .. and ugly surprise.  I think the obvious argument was missed.  If the state can force the elector to vote according to the way the party dictates - then why can't it dictate how the elector will vote ... otherwise? Logically, if NY can say .. democrat elector, you must vote for X, then why can't NY state say democrat elector you must vote for X (R).

After re-reading the testimony here is what I think will happen. The Court will not find it unconstitutional if an elector is sworn to an oath in a Court and then does not follow through then they can be punished for perjury. They will find a state can set conditions right up to the time if the vote and remove anyone who says they are not going to vote the way expected. If they are allowed to vote their vote will count no matter how they voted. What if they voted against state’s wishes. There is nothing saying the states can’t punish for that but the term elector as opposed to delegate means ‘their discretion’. Tough one but a ruling that is narrow to this case might happen. It will say not done right in these cases but not unconstitutional if set-up right by the ‘legal’ oath.

Supreme Court just delayed arguments due to Coronavirus. They might not get to this. You could say originally the State Legislature chose the elector and then the Elector met with other Electors and chose the President. Happened in first two elections but thereafter it has been the Electors are nameless bodies following their state’s dictates. The 12th Amendment states the States have the power to chose their Electors. After thinking about this it could well be that they can set expectations for Electors after they are chosen and punish if those are not met. Court could take middle way and say Constitution says nothing about what an elector is beyond their role as voter but does give a State the power to chose them. It can have criteria for the chose. So status quo? Elector can vote anyway and State can fine. It is up to the State to chose people to agree to do their bidding. The Court seems to be originalist but overturn 200 years of process? I have gone back and forth on this but this is my final answer.

So both statutes have to be invalidated.

SCOTUS is unlikely to officially rule on this issue, although if they do they will be seriously split as both sides have much to gain or lose by either supporting or not supporting faithless voters. In all fairness, fining faithless Electoral college voters is the enforcement of democracy. What is the purpose of voting if the EC is going to vote however they feel like. Then, for those justices where politics takes precedent, why wouldn't they find it unconstitutional to fine someone when they retain party control through allowing faithless votes? I could easily see RBG stating it is unconstitutional, Roberts saying it is not, Sotomayer voting it is not, Kavanaugh is a no and could not begin to assess anyone elses attitude towards the subject matter.

NCLS.Org: Article II states: “[e]ach State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a Number of Electors.” The Twelfth Amendment states that electors “vote by [distinct] ballot for president and vice president,” and that the candidates receiving votes for president or vice president constituting a majority of the electors appointed are elected to those respective offices.
The Tenth Circuit concluded that Colorado lacks the authority to require electors to vote for the candidate receiving the most votes because “the definitions of elector, vote, and ballot [contained in Article II and the Twelfth Amendment] have a common theme: they all imply the right to make a choice or voice an individual opinion.” The Washington Supreme Court upheld the state law writing:“The people of the state do not vote for presidential electors. Rather, they vote for presidential candidates.” I am thinking that the State has the right to chose the Elector any way they want but once chosen the Electors were set-up as an independent decision body. There are no add-ons in the Constitution. Changed my mind on this after more research and thinking about it.

While the first amendment states that congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances, those are individuals rights who have not entered into a contract.  
Washington has ruled to uphold the fine, Colorado has ruled on the side of the elector, putting the split at 50/50 and as of January 22, the Supreme Court has announced they will hear the cases.  There has been precedence set, in the 1952 case Ray vs Blair, the Supreme Court held that “presidential electors exercise a federal function in balloting for President and Vice-President but they are not federal officers or agents” suggesting that states may retain more control over an elector than they do over a sitting member of Congress or a president. Electors, according to Ray, “act by authority of the state that in turn receives its authority from the Federal Constitution.”

I believe they will uphold the decision, so my choice should be 7%.   I misread the question. What I mean is, no they will not find the fining unconstitutional.  The way the question was framed was confusing.   As a Washington State resident, this peaked my interest.  From the readings, and the WA State Supreme Court's decision.  I predict that the Supreme Court will uphold the decision.  In Hamilton's Federal No. 6, though he indeed intend the electoral college as a backstop, in his words, "A small number of persons, selected by their fellow-citizens from the general mass, will be most likely to possess the information and discernment requisite to so complicated an investigation."  But in the case of WA's electors, they were not selected by the masses, the masses voted directly for their Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidate of choice.   Further, in as recent as 2017 it was upheld in Arizona as well that electors were intended to be the voice and pen of the people, "presidential electors were understood to be instruments for expressing the will of those who selected them, not independent agents authorized to exercise their own judgment." Keith E. Whittington, Originalism, Constitutional Construction, and the Problem of Faithless Electors, 59 ARIZ. L. REV . 903, 911 (2017). I have to admit, I may be biased here.  It is an unconscionable amount of hubris, in this age of technology, to spurn the popular vote of the people to "vote your conscious" when you have made a pledge to be an instrument of the people.

I really have not spent any time analyzing this case.  The questions is who benefits in this highly partisan climate.  The four liberal justices will likely vote to limit or reduce the slant the electoral college gives small conservative states.  I suspect their dissent will be something usual.   The four solid conservatives, Thomas, Alito, Kavanaugh and Gorsuch will be strongly in favor of any law, including this one, which bolsters the electoral college.  Everyone always says Roberts is different.  He is concerned about the good reputation and non-partisan credibility of the court.  Well, maybe, but every timer there is a case that could slant the field toward the conservatives, he votes to do so.   Hence, I think he will vote with the conservatives.   I know I have focused on the politics without discussing the legal issues and theories at all.  However, most legal theories on this issue are results oriented.  For example, the doctrine of original intent is only followed by its conservative proponents when it yields a result the conservatives like--otherwise they ignore it.  See for example,  Bush v. Gore where Justice Thomas who correctly stated that the equal protection clause was only intended to apply to race cases, voted to apply the doctrine of equal  protection to an election case where there was no issue of race.  He did so because to do otherwise might have resulted in Al Gore becoming president.

This question is not can the state control the electors but can the state fine an elector for breaking their pledge when being appointed.  Maybe the point of the fine is to control the elector or maybe the fine is to limit the pool of candidates for elector to only those who will not vote in bad faith. The petitioner are saying the purpose of the fine is to control the elector after being appointed (probaly intrudes on federal roles).  Washington is saying its a fine for making a false pledge (definetly a State role).  A $1000 fine is not going to control an elector decision. A $100,000 fine probably would control the elector decision.
I think the court fudges and says the State can fine but the fine can not be so large as to prevent the elector from executing their independent judgement to select an elector.  Why not just say the State is not allowed to levy any fine? Because the State has the right to establish the conditions for the appointment of electors and if an elector intentionally violates those conditions then there should be a penalty for bad faith.  As I said its a fudge. They fudge to keep the ruling narrow, no large sweeping opinions.  Just recognize what everyone agrees on. Electors make a choice, States appoint electors, and the current system has fines. The decision can be written not to upset Blair.  What the decision accomplishes is a flag to electors that they can vote their conscience, and more will do just that, and we have more court cases in the future. Heck, this  could even become a whole new right/left split for the voting population, like Whigs vs Federalists.

Thinking more carefully on this (although not an American legal expert): As best as I can tell, this isn't a (directly) 'party line' vote, but rather depends heavily on judicial philosophy (albeit one which correlates with the 'liberal/conservative' split). My guess is that originalists are more likely to side with plaintiffs, given the constitutional language indicating electors are meant to exercise their judgement rather than quasi-ceremonially confirm the state vote (and thus fining them for fulfilling their constitutional obligation seems unacceptable).  Other schools of thought are likely to be much less sympathetic, and more likely to attend to the risks of political fallout if faithless electors became common (or gave a different determination of the result), or to a general norm of democracy which this could be seen to undermine. So, my guesswork on the Justices (likelihood of voting 'yes'): Thomas: Arch-originalist (~95%)
Ginsburg: Not sympathetic to originalism (~10%)
Breyer: Notably pragmatist (~5%) 
Roberts: Pragmatist, and politically sensitive (~10%)
Alito: Seems hard to guess - reliably conservative, but particularist, and generally in favour of states rights etc. (~40%)
Sotomayor: Also hard to guess, I suspect would be inclined to follow Breyer, Ginsburg etc. (~20%)
Kagan: Pragmatist (~10%) 
Gorsuch: Originalist leanings (~80%)
Kavanaugh: Reliably conservative, and so perhaps some 'originalist' style leanings (55%) Which gives ~ 3-4 votes. Another way of looking at it, beyond T + Gor + K, maybe A too, but then the most likely swing vote is Roberts, where I guess they are fairly unlikely to provoke the likely opprobrium. I guess I'll get a clearer sense from remarks at trial etc.

They'll want to get the issue decided promptly so there will be a clear answer for this year's election.  There is no explicit constitutional basis to forbid states from instructing their electors, and fining them for violating instructions.  The originalist mystics and the states' rights fundamentalists will see this immediately.  However, both of those cults have in the past proven impressively elastic in their application of their ostensibly rock-hard principles, so this isn't a shoo-in. There are instructions that would be unconstitutional--for example, forbidding electors from voting for anyone who hadn't released their tax returns.  This would be charming, but states aren't allowed to add eligibility requirements to the explicit provisions of the Constitution.  They discovered this a few years ago when a few tried to impose term limits on members of Congress.   However, this case doesn't involve anything like that.

In Chiafalo v. Washington, will the Supreme Court rule that the state of Washington's fining of presidential electors for failing to vote for the nominee of their party is unconstitutional? By agreeing to hear the case they have made a statement.

I think the Supreme Court will defer to states as to how they manage their electors.  As I read the Constitution, the electors are part of a slate but are not bound to vote for any particular person.  I think the Court will defer to the states on this.  My casual reading of the Constitution and the 12th Amendment is there is no restriction on how electors are bound to behave with respect to this issue.

In Chiafalo v. Washington, will the Supreme Court rule that the state of Washington's fining of presidential electors for failing to vote for the nominee of their party is unconstitutional? There are cascaded "ifs" in this question and questions I cannot answer, but it is a good one to follow. I'll be at a respectful distance.
In my reading, it is unconstitutional.

Entering an initial forecast for starters.  Learned thus far (reposted excerpts): "In Ray v. Blair (1952), the Supreme Court held that a party’s proposed slate of electors may be required to pledge that they will vote for their party’s nominee. But Ray also left unanswered the question of what happens if an elector violates this pledge after they are appointed to the Electoral College.  Ray held that “even if such promises of candidates for the electoral college are legally unenforceable ... it would not follow that the requirement of a pledge” is unconstitutional. But that holding explicitly avoids the question of whether an elector’s pledge to support their party’s nominee can be enforced if violated. Chiafalo and Baca now place that question squarely before the justices — and the argument that faithless electors may choose not to vote for the candidate they pledged to support is hardly frivolous. Should the Supreme Court side with this argument, they could turn the Electoral College into an even less democratic institution — one where the 538 men and women chosen as electors wield full discretion to choose a president, regardless of what the voters have to say." Source (opinion/analysis) article link: https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2020/1/22/21074453/supreme-court-faithless-electors-chiafalo-baca. Also considered: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/us/supreme-court-electoral-college.html First guess is that, practically speaking, the current (generally 'conservative'-leaning) Supreme Court - if they rule - will find arguments in support of not "blowing up" the Electoral College (as presently interpreted). Particularly in a presidential election year..

https://www.heraldnet.com/news/supreme-court-to-hear-washington-case-of-faithless-electors/ It would appear that States have the power to grant political parties the right to select electors however they wish. It also seems clear that there are circumstances in which the framers clearly intended for electors to be free to change their votes, although they did not explicitly prohibit states from preventing this for their own electors. To some extent this flexibility reflected the communication limitations of the time, but it also reflects a continuing need for the election process to always yield an unambiguous winner. The question in my mind is how SCOTUS will view this historical legacy in light of modern traditions and needs; and how they will balance the right of States to set their own rules in the absence of clear wording in the constitution.  In the absence of clear precedent, my guess is that they will choose on the basis of: 
1) the literal language of the constitution on the issue
2) the intention of the framers as best it can be inferred 
3) Republican and/or Democrat bias of each member I don't know the political argument, but I would assume that conservative members will generally want to allow States to require electors to vote as committed; and Democrats will want electors to be free to change their vote. However I could be 180 off on that. If that's the case then it seems like there are a lot of headwinds to SCOTUS finding in favor of the electors.
